natural problem:
For a complex number $z,$ compute the minimum value of
\[|z + 5 - 3i| + |z - 7 + 2i|.\]
natural solution: Geometrically, $|z + 5 - 3i|$ is the distance between the complex numbers $z$ and $-5 + 3i$ in the complex plane, and $|z - 7 + 2i|$ is the distance between $z$ and $7 - 2i.$ [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, Z;

By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of the distances is minimized when $z$ lies on the line segment connecting the two complex numbers $-5 + 3i$ and $7- 2i,$ in which case the sum of the distances is simply $|(5 - 3i) - (-7 + 2i)| = |12 - 5i| = \boxed{13}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "(cmod (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + cmod (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)) \<ge> 13"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For a complex number $z,$ compute the minimum value of
\[|z + 5 - 3i| + |z - 7 + 2i|.\] The final Answer is 13
 ### Proof
 Geometrically, $|z + 5 - 3i|$ is the distance between the complex numbers $z$ and $-5 + 3i$ in the complex plane, and $|z - 7 + 2i|$ is the distance between $z$ and $7 - 2i.$ [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, Z;
 A = (-5,3); B = (7,-2); Z = (6,6); draw(A--B); draw(A--Z--B); dot("$-5 + 3i$", A, NW); dot("$7 - 2i$", B, SE); dot("$z$", Z, NE); [/asy]
 By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of the distances is minimized when $z$ lies on the line segment connecting the two complex numbers $-5 + 3i$ and $7- 2i,$ in which case the sum of the distances is simply $|(5 - 3i) - (-7 + 2i)| = |12 - 5i| = \boxed{13}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "(cmod (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + cmod (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)) \<ge> 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The sum of the absolute values (or magnitudes) of a complex number $z$ plus $5$ minus $3i$ and $z$ minus $7$ plus $2i$ is greater than or equal to $13$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "(cmod (z + (5 - 3 * \<i>)) + cmod (z - (7 - 2 * \<i>))) = 13"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For a complex number $z,$ compute the minimum value of
\[|z + 5 - 3i| + |z - 7 + 2i|.\] The final Answer is 13

 A = (-5,3); B = (7,-2); Z = (6,6); draw(A--B); draw(A--Z--B); dot("$-5 + 3i$", A, NW); dot("$7 - 2i$", B, SE); dot("$z$", Z, NE); [/asy]
 By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of the distances is minimized when $z$ lies on the line segment connecting the two complex numbers $-5 + 3i$ and $7- 2i,$ in which case the sum of the distances is simply $|(5 - 3i) - (-7 + 2i)| = |12 - 5i| = \boxed{13}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "(cmod (z + (5 - 3 * \<i>)) + cmod (z - (7 - 2 * \<i>))) = 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find a complex number $z$ such that the sum of the distances from $z$ to $5 - 3i$ and from $z$ to $7 - 2i$ is $13$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "Inf {cmod (z + Complex (Re 5) (Im (-3))) + cmod (z - Complex (Re 7) (Im 2)) | z. True} = 13"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For a complex number $z,$ compute the minimum value of
\[|z + 5 - 3i| + |z - 7 + 2i|.\] The final Answer is 13
 ### Proof

 A = (-5,3); B = (7,-2); Z = (6,6); draw(A--B); draw(A--Z--B); dot("$-5 + 3i$", A, NW); dot("$7 - 2i$", B, SE); dot("$z$", Z, NE); [/asy]
 By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of the distances is minimized when $z$ lies on the line segment connecting the two complex numbers $-5 + 3i$ and $7- 2i,$ in which case the sum of the distances is simply $|(5 - 3i) - (-7 + 2i)| = |12 - 5i| = \boxed{13}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "Inf {cmod (z + Complex (Re 5) (Im (-3))) + cmod (z - Complex (Re 7) (Im 2)) | z. True} = 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the minimum possible sum of the distances of a complex number $z$ from $5 - 3i$ and $7 + 2i$. The final answer is $13$.

theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "min (cmod(z + 5 - 3*\<i>)) (cmod(z - 7 + 2*\<i>)) = 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the complex number $z$ such that the minimum distance from $z$ to either $5 - 3i$ or $7 + 2i$ is 13 units.

fixes z :: complex

a_5.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes z :: complex and d :: real
assumes h0 : "d = norm (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + norm (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)"
shows  "Inf {d | z. d = norm (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + norm (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)} = 13"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For a complex number $z,$ compute the minimum value of
\[|z + 5 - 3i| + |z - 7 + 2i|.\] The final Answer is 13
 ### Proof
 Geometrically, $|z + 5 - 3i|$ is the distance between the complex numbers $z$ and $-5 + 3i$ in the complex plane, and $|z - 7 + 2i|$ is the distance between $z$ and $7 - 2i.$ [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, Z;
 A = (-5,3); B = (7,-2); Z = (6,6); draw(A--B); draw(A--Z--B); dot("$-5 + 3i$", A, NW); dot("$7 - 2i$", B, SE); dot("$z$", Z, NE); [/asy]
 By the Triangle Inequality, the sum of the distances is minimized when $z$ lies on the line segment connecting the two complex numbers $-5 + 3i$ and $7- 2i,$ in which case the sum of the distances is simply $|(5 - 3i) - (-7 + 2i)| = |12 - 5i| = \boxed{13}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes z :: complex and d :: real
assumes h0 : "d = norm (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + norm (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)"
shows  "Inf {d | z. d = norm (z + 5 - 3 * \<i>) + norm (z - 7 + 2 * \<i>)} = 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the minimum possible value of the sum of distances from any complex number $z$ to the points $-5 + 3i$ and $7 - 2i$. The final answer is $13$.

theorem
fixes z :: complex
shows  "Min {norm (z + Complex (Re 5) (Im (-3))), norm (z - Complex (Re 7) (Im 2))} = 13"

fixes z :: complex
shows  "Min {norm (z + Complex (Re 5) (Im (-3))), norm (z - Complex (Re 7) (Im 2))} = 13"

a_6.informal problem: Find the minimum distance between a complex number $z$ and the complex numbers $(5 - 3i)$ and $(7 + 2i)$. The smallest distance is $13$.
